I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 
investment of up to $35,000,000 in Multiples Private Equity Fund III Limited in India. 
 
2.  Multiples Private Equity Fund III Limited (the feeder fund) is a Mauritian public limited 
company, which will invest in Multiples Private Equity Fund III (the fund), a targeted $750 million 
Indian investment trust.1 The fund proposes to invest in growth stage opportunities in middle-
market companies (with enterprise values ranging from $150 million to $500 million) in India.2 It 
may also selectively consider control-oriented and early-stage investment opportunities. Target 
sectors are consumer, finance, health care and pharmaceuticals, and technology.  
 
3.  Rationale for proposed ADB assistance. India is currently the world’s seventh-largest 
economy and its economy grew at an average of 7% annually since 2008. The Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) forecasts growth of 7.3% in 2018 and 7.6% in 2019.3 The rapid economic growth is 
expanding India’s middle class and increasing disposable incomes, which is in turn driving 
discretionary consumption-led opportunities across several sectors, including finance, health 
care, and consumer services.4 Growth in these sectors is being driven by (i) a substantial increase 
in discretionary spending; (ii) the rise of tier 2 cities and rural towns, which will be India’s next 
growth engines; and (iii) favorable demographics, with approximately 60% of the population in the 
working age bracket. Companies in these sectors require capital for expansion to enable them to 
meet the needs of India’s growing middle class. 
 
4.  India has undergone a series of macro reforms since the general elections of 2014. Newly 
enacted policies are expected to enhance the transparency and efficiency of India’s economy, 
fostering an improved business environment for private companies, and a favorable investment 
climate for institutional investors.5 Given this context, ADB’s investment in Multiples Private Equity 
Fund III Limited will help (i) provide adequate capital to private sector companies and catalyze 
their  development  while  tapping  into  India’s  growing  middle  class,  (ii)  support  the  Indian 
government’s efforts to increase the transparency and efficiency of the economy by improving 
corporate governance of portfolio companies, and (iii) contribute to private sector job creation and 
increased tax revenues for the Government of India. 
 
II.  THE FUND 
 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
 
5.  Description. Multiples Alternate Asset Management Private Limited (Multiples) is an 
India-focused, independent, and well-respected private equity fund manager. Founder and chief 
executive officer (CEO) Renuka Ramnath, a seasoned private equity investment professional, 
established Multiples in 2009. Prior to forming Multiples, Ramnath was managing director and

CEO of ICICI Venture, one of India’s earliest alternative asset managers, where she managed 
more than $2 billion in private equity, mezzanine, and real estate assets.6 [This information has 
been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information Policy, 
para. 17.2.(v)].7 Multiples has a 14-member investment team based in Mumbai, India.  
 
6.  Multiples is currently raising its third private equity fund, Multiples Private Equity Fund III, 
which is established as an investment trust registered with the Securities and Exchange Board of 
India as a category 2 alternative investment fund (AIF) vehicle, with a target capitalization of $750 
million (footnote 1). Multiples Equity Fund Trustee Private Limited, incorporated in India, is the 
trustee of the fund. The trustee has appointed Multiples Alternate Asset  Management Limited 
(Multiples), a company incorporated in India, to act as the fund manager under an investment 
management agreement.8  
 
7.  Investment  identification. In  the  process  of market  mapping  India’s  private  equity 
landscape, ADB met with over 35 Indian fund managers that provide growth equity capital to 
small- to middle-market companies. ADB shortlisted five of these fund managers—including 
Multiples—as potential partners, based on their alignment with ADB’s private equity investment 
guidelines, including performance track record, access to deal flow, and operational expertise. 
 
8.  ADB first met the Multiples team in February 2015 and since then has actively tracked the 
platform through regular interactions with Ramnath and her team. These meetings, as well as 
discussions with existing limited partners, confirmed that Ramnath has developed Multiples into 
a high-quality institutional platform, as reflected by its proprietary investment frameworks to 
ensure consistency in process, a collaborative culture that emphasizes a cohesive approach to 
deal evaluation, and governance and reporting standards in line with global best practices. ADB 
was also attracted to Multiples’ investment approach of identifying and partnering with best-in-
class  companies  across  sectors through  both minority  and  control,  and  occasionally  listed 
investments. These targeted companies are established businesses, although Multiples also 
selectively  invests  in  early-stage  opportunities  where  valuations  and  growth  prospects  are 
attractive. In all cases, however, Multiples positions itself as a long-term partner to entrepreneurs 
that  helps  investee  companies  become  industry-leading  businesses  and  create  value  for 
shareholders. The proposed investment would allow ADB to contribute to India’s continued 
economic growth through an established private equity platform that invests in sectors closely 
aligned with ADB’s developmental mandate, including financial services and health care. 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
 
9.  The fund aims to make 11−14 investments of $20 million to $80 million each. The fund 
may also consider transactions above $100 million, for which co-investment capital will be 
required. The fund’s targeted sectors are consumer, finance, health care and pharmaceuticals, 
and technology. The fund will primarily invest in minority growth opportunities but has the flexibility 
to opportunistically pursue control-oriented and/or early-stage investments, as well as private 
investments in public companies. 
  
10.  Multiples frequently identifies companies undergoing generational ownership changes,

current stress in the Indian banking system and tightening of asset regulations by India’s central 
bank, Multiples has the experience and expertise to facilitate a company turnaround, although 
such investments will be made selectively.

staff are in supporting functions, including investor relations, fund administration, legal and 
compliance, finance, and accounting.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
20.  ADB will provide an equity investment of up to $35,000,000 in Multiples Private Equity 
Fund III Limited. ADB’s proposed investment will not exceed 10% of the fund’s aggregate 
committed capital and will not result in ADB being the single largest investor in the fund. 
 
B.  Financial Analysis of Expected Returns and Assumptions

C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  Exit strategy. The fund will have a 10-year term from final closing, which may be extended 
by two 1-year extensions, and further extended subject to AIF regulations in India and approval 
by two-thirds of investors by value of investment. The anticipated exit strategies for the fund’s 
investments include public offerings, trade sales of portfolio companies to local and foreign 
strategic buyers, and secondary sales to other private equity funds.  
 
23.  Reporting arrangements. Multiples will provide ADB with (i) quarterly reports; and (ii) 
audited annual financial statements, an annual valuation, an overview of the portfolio with brief 
information on each portfolio company’s performance and valuation, an annual development 
effectiveness monitoring report, and an annual environmental and social monitoring report. ADB 
will review this information and follow-up with the fund manager if more information or clarification 
are needed. If the information received from the fund manager raises issues that could impair the 
value of ADB’s investment in the fund, ADB could decide to put the fund on a watch list for more 
frequent review and closer attention.

D.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
25.  Capital mobilization and strategy validation. At $750 million, this will be Multiples 
largest fund to date. ADB’s participation as a first close investor will, therefore, help anchor the 
fund and attract additional institutional capital to enable the fund to reach its target size. ADB’s 
commitment to the fund will allow Multiples to achieve a diversified, well-balanced institutional 
investor base for the fund. In addition, ADB’s participation will provide validation of the fund’s 
strategy, and its commercial and developmental attributes. 
 
26.  Raising standards. Multiples will be required to implement an ESMS acceptable to ADB 
that requires it to oblige its portfolio companies to comply with ADB’s environment and social 
safeguard requirements and report to ADB on development indicators. 
 
27.  Gender equality. ADB’s participation may promote gender equity in certain investee 
companies of the fund. Multiples was founded and is led by a woman who believes in mentoring 
women for future leadership.16 In this respect, Multiples has indicated that it is amenable to 
adopting some specific gender-inclusive actions for the fund, which will be developed with ADB’s 
assistance.  
 
28.  Knowledge transfer. Multiples values and will seek to leverage ADB’s financial services 
domain expertise and networks that might assist in the fund’s value creation and exit initiatives.

IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
36.  Impact. The equity investment is aligned with the following impact: private equity funding 
for middle-market companies in India increased, contributing to the growth of the economy, 
creation of quality jobs, and improvement of business efficiency and transparency. 
 
37.  Outcome. The equity investment will have the following outcome: financial and social 
sustainability of private equity investments in India demonstrated. 
 
38.  Outputs. The equity investment will have the following outputs: (i) Multiples Private Equity 
Fund III Limited is established, (ii) the capital is invested by the fund among 11−14 companies 
within the proposed 5-year investment period, and (iii) the gender-inclusive approach of Multiples 
is strengthened.17 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  
 
39.  Consistency with ADB strategy. The proposed investment in the fund aligns strongly 
with  operational  priorities  outlined  in  ADB’s  Strategy  2030.18 These  include  (i)  addressing 
remaining poverty and reducing inequalities by generating quality jobs and achieving better health 
for all, and (ii) accelerating progress in gender equality by scaling up support for gender equality. 
Strategy 2030 also supports expanding private sector operations, including using private equity 
to extend reach and diversify into other sectors; supporting greater financial inclusion; and 
strengthening the finance sector and capital markets. Given its track record, Multiples is uniquely 
positioned to deliver on the Strategy 2030 themes through investments such as RBL Bank and 
Vastu Housing that promote financial inclusion and access to affordable housing, and Vikram 
Hospital and Natco Pharma that deliver high-quality health care products and services. 
 
40.  Consistency with country strategy. The investment in the fund is consistent with the 
country partnership strategy, 2018−2022 for India; it (i) highlights the need for recapitalization of 
the banking subsector to resolve its stressed assets; (ii) includes support for affordable housing, 
financial  inclusion  and  the  health  sectors  as  strategic  priorities;  and  (iii)  focusses  on  the 
importance of gender equality.19  
 
41.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The ADB Operational 
Plan for Health, 2015–2020 strongly supports private sector approaches to address quality, 
efficiency, and financing issues in the health sector.20 Furthermore, the ADB Financial Sector 
Operational Plan 2011 and its subsequent review in 2017 recommend retaining the focus on 
finance sector development through investments in banks and non-bank financial institutions and

V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions   
 
43.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009). 
 
44.  Category FI. The project is classified category FI for impacts on environment, involuntary 
resettlement, and indigenous peoples in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
ADB has assessed the fund’s potential environmental and social impacts, the risks associated 
with the existing and future portfolio, and its commitment and capacity for environmental and 
social management as part of the safeguards due diligence process. In its first fund, which 
invested during 2011–2014, Multiples invested in companies involved in oilfield equipment, rice 
mills, apparel, textiles, and water purifier manufacturing; bank and nonbank financial institutions; 
a specialist hospital; energy trading; and new media and e-commerce platforms. Multiples’ second 
fund began investing in 2015, and targeted companies engaged in bank and mortgage finance 
institutions, clothing and pharmaceutical manufacturing, cinemas, human resources services, and 
an online gaming platform.  
 
45.  Multiples engaged KPMG, a global audit and professional services firm, to develop its 
environmental,  social,  and  governance  (ESG)  vision  and  objectives,  as  well  as  a  policy 
framework. Multiples has also hired staff with specific environmental and social management 
responsibilities including environmental and social due diligence, screening, monitoring, and ESG 
enhancement of its portfolio companies. Multiples applies the exclusion list of the International 
Finance Corporation; engages external experts to screen, assess, and monitor environmental 
and social risks and impacts of investee companies; and requires portfolio companies to operate 
in accordance with applicable national laws and regulations, and to implement any corrective 
action plan, if appropriate. In consultation with the International Finance Corporation, for its 
second fund Multiples limited the extent of application of environmental and social requirements 
for each investee based on the type of company and level of influence it has with the company. 
Investment  decisions  are  also  informed  by  an  internal  ESG  review  of  potential  portfolio 
companies, independent of the environmental and social due diligence.  
  
46.  To strengthen Multiple’s ESMS implementation for this fund in compliance with the ADB 
Safeguard Policy Statement, Multiples agreed to enhance its ESG framework to (i) screen and 
categorize potential portfolio companies according to the ADB Safeguard Policy Statement 
categorization and apply ADB’s Prohibited Investment Activities List; (ii) apply its environmental 
and social requirements to all portfolio companies; (iii) prepare environmental and social training

submit  timely,  relevant  environmental  and  social  due  diligence  documentation  and  annual 
environmental  and  social  reports  to  ADB;  and  (vi)  increase  reporting  requirements  for 
environmental and social incidences and breaches by portfolio companies.22 The enhancement 
of Multiples ESG framework will be a condition precedent to ADB’s first disbursement. ADB will 
reserve the right to be exempted from contributing capital to any proposed investment classified 
as category A (for any safeguard classifications) and any proposed investment that it assesses 
as being noncompliant with the ESG framework. 
 
47.  Some gender elements. This investment is categorized having some gender elements. 
Multiples is committed to implementing measures to promote gender equality and/or women’s 
empowerment in its business activities following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998). It will submit periodic reports on implementation of gender measures to ADB. The ESG 
framework sets out requirements for compliance, as applicable, with national labor laws and 
measures to comply with the internationally recognized core labor standards, pursuant to ADB’s 
Social Protection Strategy.23 The ESG framework will also contain requirements, as applicable, 
for information disclosure and consultation with affected people. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy  
 
48.  Multiples was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating 
to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that 
the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance.

VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
51.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $35,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources in Multiples Private 
Equity Fund III Limited in India, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President
